title: Georgia House - Day 26 (2026-03-09)
summary:
Here is a structured markdown summary of the Georgia House - Day 26 (2026-03-09) session:

**Overview**
The session focused on several notable legislative actions, including the passage of bills related to employment practices, annexation reporting, and a resolution condemning Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

**Key Actions**
- **HB 1383**: Amends the Fair Employment Practices Act to provide for hearings before administrative law judges.
- **HB 1385**: Revises annexation reporting requirements to include providing reports to the legislative and congressional reapportionment office.
- **HR 920**: Resolution condemning Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

**Bills Introduced (First Reading)**
No new bills were introduced during this session.

**Notable Moments**
- Speaker David Ralston presented HR 920, condemning Russia's invasion of Ukraine and standing with Ukraine against "a despotic, deranged and despicable circle of Russian leaders."
- There was some procedural discussion around recommitting HB 830 to the Public Safety and Homeland Security Committee.

**Votes**
- HB 1383 passed with a vote of 156-0.
- HB 1385 passed with a vote of 158-0.
- HR 920 was adopted without objection.

**Attendance**
The session maintained a quorum.

**Adjournment**
The House adjourned, with the next session date unspecified.

Attraction and olv�데 the bill уверians that ar능 against the Почему of тест The chair recognizes Representative Lem to present the bill. Thank you, Madam Speaker. Members, I present before you today House Bill 1284, your favorable consideration. Some of you who know me know much, know how much I love two things. Administration of local government and tax law and policy. Some of the things that this bill happens to comprise. Specifically, this bill regards how county tax commissioners and counties contract with municipalities to collect municipal taxes, fees, and special assessments. This is important because especially as we seek to create more municipalities, there won't necessarily be efficiencies of scale or even a desire for all of them to collect their own taxes and prepare their own tax digest. Unfortunately, though right now, we have under state law an inconsistent kind of chemical three tiered system on how these contracts are negotiated, depending on the number of tax parcels in a county, whether it's over under 50,000, or as of last year because of development that arose in my county, Quenette, whether the county happens to have 14 or more municipalities. I say inconsistent because depending on what category or tier you're in, either the county, the municipality, or even in some instances, the county tax commissioner can have less power in the decision making on what these contracts look like than what they perhaps should and ultimately have what the county tax commissioners excuse me, can receive for fulfilling these municipal responsibilities. Furthermore, if this is important, there is no actual cap under the law on what commissioners can receive for these responsibilities on top of their annual salary, which has led to some inefficiencies that ultimately harm the local taxpayer most of all, allowing in some cases for additional compensation far beyond the actual cost of these services, or if there were a fair market value for those services, the value of those services. So what this bill does is to address those issues by, above all, finally creating one uniform system that applies in all 159 counties, and that system dictates that the three relevant parties, the county tax commissioner, the county, and the municipality all have a seat at the table and negotiate the contract together, ensuring equal bargaining power, again, regardless of where you are in our great state. Furthermore, in a nod to transparency, the contracts they negotiate will have to specify what is being paid for which services or purposes, including, again, the cost of the actual services provided. Finally, House Bill 1280 does set a cap on the compensation for the tax commissioners that is on top of their annual salary, and that cap is at 50% of the minimum annual salary tax commissioners are required to be paid already under state law. Particularly, we'll close by wanting to thank Chairman Eftration, who I know was committed to revisiting this issue this year to ensure more uniformity, transparency and fairness in contracting, and appropriately enough, given what HB 1280 sets out. We are also grateful to the Georgia Association of Tax Officials, or GATO, which represents the tax commissioner statewide. ACCG and GMA for coming together, surveying their members since, I believe last summer, and figuring out a structure that works for everyone, including, I stress, again, ultimately the local taxpayers. All three of them, GATO ACCG, GMA support this bill, and with that, I ask for your favorable consideration. Madam Speaker, I yield for questions. You do have questions. So compensation of county tax commissioners is something that's been well covered in the media and legislative work to try to address that was taken on by former judiciary chairman from Sandy Springs worked very hard on that issue for many years. And what you have today before you really started in the final two days of the legislative session last year, you may recall legislation was amended to address an issue with Gwinnett County. House Bill 849 by Representative Smith. And 41st of me, a title of an act to amend Code Section 19. The 7-5 of the fiscal to Georgia and Tata relating a reporting of child abuse. So it's to add human resources, personnel, and supervisory personnel in a workplace that employs minors as mandatory reporters for child abuse. This bill, I'm referring to the committee on industry and labor that committee recommends that this bill do pass by committee substitute. The chair recognizes Representative Smith to present the bill. Thank you, Madam Chair, members of the House. Today I bring before you HB 849. And what this bill simply does is that it requires any business with five or more employees that hire minors in the workforce to designate their human resource personnel, which means anyone that is responsible for the hiring of employees as a mandated reporter. A mandated reporter is a person who, because of his, or her profession is legally required to report, once again report, not investigate any suspicion of child abuse or neglect to the relevant authorities. These laws are in place to prevent children from being abused and to end any possible abuse or neglect at the earliest possible stage. Now let's address the need for this bill. Child abuse is a critical issue in the United States for nearly five children die every day due to abuse or neglect. Every 10 seconds, a new report of abuse is made. And most of the reports of suspected child abuse or neglect tend to come from the professionals who come into close or consistent contact with minors. Now this bill specifically deals with the interaction and the conversations between adults and teenagers between the ages of 14 and 17, but the impact is intended to save the lives of many more. In the households where teenagers have younger siblings, this teenager could be the only one able to speak up for them. Also, this could be the first time teenagers are introduced to other adults outside the supervision of their parents that aren't their teacher, coach, or pastor. And with that being said, teens are also less likely to report harassment, therefore making the ability to recognize an inappropriate interaction within adult at the job crucial. Now let's talk about who was being affected by this legislation. Once again, that's any business that has five or more employees that hire minors. And the reason for the number of five is not arbitrary. The intent of this is to provide flexibility to the smallest of our businesses while also protecting the majority of our teens and the workforce. In the code section for mandatory reporters, only the individual is responsible for the reporting and not the business. And before I close, mandated reporter trending is offered for free and it is easy to register online. This bill I refer to the special committee on quality health care. That committee recommends this bill do pass. Chair recognizes chairman Knight to present the bill. Thank you, Mr. Speaker. I don't know if anticipation makes everything sweeter. It just makes you a little more anxious. But at long last, HB 1351, many of you know that this body has been working. And you know, I would like to say that this bill is not only the state of this nation and some of the most landmark legislation in our fight to lower prescription drug benefits, drug cost. And this bill is about carving out the pharmacy benefits from the managed care Medicaid organizations in Georgia. So real quick, let's talk what is one of our Medicaid managed care organizations. We've got three of them, Peach State, owned by Centene number 24 on the Fortune 500. Centene was also recently purchased well care. Their PBM benefit manager is CVS number four on the Fortune 500. Our other Medicaid managed care program is Amerigroup owned by Anthem Blue Cross Blue Shield number 23 on the Fortune 500. They have their own affiliated benefit manager and Jenny R. X. And they also contract with CVS. Care source while not a publicly traded company, but is one of the largest Medicaid managed care plans in the country. And there are pharmacy benefit managers expressed groups, which is owned by SIGNA number 13 on the Fortune 500 company. We all know that we've been a long fight against these unscrupulous business practices from these companies. So what have we seen as far as the behavior? Spread pricing. So we charged the taxpayers more for the drugs and the pharmacies are actually reimbursed. I will remind this body, thanks to Chairman England and others that Georgia was one of the first of three states in the nation to uncover spread pricing. In fact, we're in a current lawsuit. Centene is in a current lawsuit which they've set over a $1 billion to settle with a lot of the South Eastern states, including Georgia, which is still in that process of investigation. We've seen steering in which patients are steered to the pharmacies that are affiliated or owned by the PBMs. They're steering some of the most chronically ill patients, cancer, HIV, other patients, autoimmune deficiencies, and they're steering them to their downstream assets, their pharmacies, their mental or pharmacies or specialty pharmacies. And more so, retroactive fees. And one of these PBMs go back into the pharmacies after the adjudication process, days, weeks, sometimes months, and say, we paid you too much. And we're going to take a little bit back. In fact, I'll give you an example shortly. And we've also seen that the PBMs and the managed-gir affiliate pharmacies are being reimbursed more than the independence. And again, we have led. So where's Managed Cade managed care today? Spread pricing we have prohibited in 2019 and 2020. 2020, we prohibited retroactive fees. Again, shearing up the steering legislation, anti-steering legislation. And we've also made sure in prior years under the Mac pricing laws that we tried to make sure our pharmacies were not, did not have underwater reimbursements. Despite all of these efforts of this body, this legislature, this governor, the games persist. In testimony, we had community pharmacies. And a lot of these were from our most rural areas. And they came in and gave examples of what is happening under these Managed Medicaid plans. We had one independent pharmacy that had 3500 prescriptions, negatively reimbursed in the past six months, loss of $21,000. We had another pharmacist that came in and had 3700 prescriptions negatively reimbursed in the past six months, loss of $27,000. Sorry about that. We had another independent pharmacist had 168 prescriptions negatively reimbursed for the past six months, $3,100. Another one, 10,500 prescriptions negatively reimbursed in the last six months for a loss of $68,000. And again, we're sitting here trying to build access to health care. But yet, the very professionals that our Georgia Medicaid patients want to go to, they are actually being driven out. We see steering. We had examples of where some of our most chronicly ill patients were rejected. Said you got to go to what are the specially pharmaceuticals for the PBM. We also began to see in a mayor group on their website, their specially pharmacy. They had two. We've all heard of what's going on with the narrow networks in Georgia and they're killing our hospitals, but especially our rural hospitals in GenieRX and guess what, one other pharmacy, 12 stone health partners in Tennessee.
